dublinCore.dc:title: 113 HR 884 IH: Members of Congress Tax Accountability Act of 2013
dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.

action.action-desc: Mr. Chaffetz introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on House Administration, and in addition to the Committee on Rules, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned

form.official-title: To require Members of Congress to disclose delinquent tax liability and to require an ethics inquiry into, and the garnishment of the wages of, a Member with Federal tax liability.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Members of Congress Tax Accountability Act of 2013.

section.header: Amendment to the Ethics in Government Act of 1978

subparagraph.text: For individuals described in section 101(f)(9), the amount of any delinquent tax liability owed to the United States or any State or local government entity.

In this paragraph, the term delinquent tax liability means any tax liability which has been assessed and with respect to which all judicial and administrative remedies have been exhausted, or have lapsed.

subsection.text: Section 102(b)(1)(A) of the Ethics in Government Act of 1978 (5 U.S.C. App.) is amended by striking paragraph (1) and inserting paragraphs (1) and (9).

section.text: If a Member of Congress reports a delinquent tax liability on the Member’s annual disclosure form required under section 102(a)(9) of the Ethics in Government Act of 1978 (as added by section 2), the appropriate congressional ethics committee shall immediately open an inquiry into the tax delinquency of that Member for purposes of—

paragraph.text: determining the total delinquent tax liability of the Member;
determining the reason the Member has incurred a delinquent tax liability;
determining whether such delinquent tax liability has reflected poorly on Congress.

section.text: A Member of Congress who discloses a delinquent tax liability under section 102(a)(9) of the Ethics in Government Act of 1978 (as added by section 2) shall, not later than 30 calendar days after filing the form, arrange with the Secretary of the Senate or the Chief Administrative Officer of the House of Representatives, as appropriate, and the Internal Revenue Service to have the Member’s salary reduced by an amount appropriate to pay the taxes owed to the United States within a reasonable time period.
In this Act, the term Member of Congress means a Senator or a Representative in, or Delegate or Resident Commissioner to, the Congress.
